title-group.article-title: Influences of climate, cattle density, and lake morphology on Sporormiella abundances in modern lake sediments in the US Great Plains

author-notes.corresp: Nancy E Parker, Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 550 N Park St, Madison WI 53706, USA. Email: neparker@wisc.edu

abstract.p: Sporormiella, a genus of coprophilous fungus, is increasingly used as a qualitative proxy for megafaunal density. Decreased spore abundances in Late-Pleistocene and Holocene sediments are thought to signal prehistoric megafaunal population declines and extinctions. However, much remains unknown regarding the dispersal, deposition, and preservation of Sporormiella, hindering interpretation. Here we collected lake-center and lake-margin surface-sediment samples from 24 lakes in a west–east transect across South Dakota, Minnesota, and Wisconsin to test whether Sporormiella abundances varied along a precipitation gradient and areas of varying grazing intensity. Unlike other pollen types, relative abundances and concentrations of Sporormiella spores were uncorrelated between lake-center and lake-margin samples. For lake-margin samples, distance-to-shoreline and county-scale cattle density were significant predictors of Sporormiella relative abundances. Only distance to shoreline was a significant predictor of Sporormiella concentrations. The positive relationship between shoreline proximity and Sporormiella abundances differs from prior reports that Sporormiella concentrations decrease away from shoreline. For lake-center samples, Sporormiella relative abundances were negatively correlated with precipitation and Sporormiella concentrations had no significant predictors. These results suggest that Sporormiella representation in lake sediments is controlled by multiple factors, including but not limited to local megaherbivore density. Sporormiella concentrations appear to be ‘noisier’ than Sporormiella relative abundances, due to within-basin sedimentary effects on pollen and spore accumulation rates. More work on Sporormiella taphonomy is critically needed to better understand the controls on its representation in late-Quaternary sediments.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: At the end of the Pleistocene, over 90 genera of the world’s megafauna (animals weighing > 44 kg) went extinct on all continents except Africa (Koch and Barnosky, 2006), with additional extinctions on Madagascar and Pacific islands during the Holocene (Burney et al., 2003; Wood et al., 2011). Paleoecologists have long debated the cause (Koch and Barnosky, 2006; Martin and Klein, 1984) and consequences (Gill et al., 2009; Owen-Smith, 1987; Robinson et al., 2005) of the late-Quaternary megafaunal extinctions. Sporormiella, a genus of coprophilous fungi, has increasingly been used as a proxy for megaherbivore population declines during the Late Pleistocene and Holocene (Burney et al., 2003; Davis, 1987; Davis and Shafer, 2006; Gill et al., 2009; Raper and Bush, 2009; Robinson et al., 2005; Wood et al., 2011) and for the introduction of domesticated megaherbivores (Davis, 1987; Davis and Shafer, 2006; van Geel et al., 2003, 2008). Spores of the fungus have been found on the dung of a wide range of extinct and extant megaherbivores including mammoth, bison, cattle and moose, as well as smaller mammals such as rabbit, porcupine and avian herbivores (Ahmed and Cain, 1972; Mead et al., 1986; Mol et al., 2001; Richardson, 2001; van Geel et al., 2008; Wood et al., 2011). In North American records, Sporormiella abundances tend to be high in Late-Pleistocene sediments, low during the Holocene, and then high again after European settlement (Cordova et al., 2011; Davis, 1987; Gill et al., 2009; Robinson et al., 2005). However, Sporormiella spores are sometimes absent at currently grazed sites (Cordova et al., 2011; Davis, 1987; Davis and Shafer, 2006; Raper and Bush, 2009) and it is also poorly understood why Sporormiella abundances are relatively low in Holocene sediments despite the survival of large herbivores and known Sporormiella hosts such as bison, elk, and deer.

There is thus a need to understand the ecological and taphonomic processes that govern the representation of Sporormiella spores in sedimentary archives. Sporormiella’s life cycle includes ingestion of spores by herbivores and passage through the digestive system (Wicklow and Angel, 1980). Spores then germinate within the dung and new fruiting bodies (ascocarps) are formed at the dung surface. These ascocarps contain asci, each of which contains several (usually eight) ascospores (Doveri, 2007). The ascocarps burst and the asci and ascospores are dispersed to the surrounding vegetation where they can be consumed once again, continuing the cycle. Alternatively, ascospores might be deposited in lake sediments or elsewhere on the landscape where they then lie dormant. Each Sporormiella ascospore consists of a chain of four or more cells (also called subspores) (Ahmed and Cain, 1972), and usually the disaggregated subspores are found in sediments; intact ascospores are uncommon and asci are rare. It is unlikely that spores disperse far from their source because of the positioning of Sporormiella and its dung source near the ground, where wind transport is ineffective (Davis and Shafer, 2006; van Geel et al., 2003). Sporormiella presence/abundance in lake sediments thus has been attributed to deposition by slopewash and short-distance aerial transport from dung in the watershed (Davis et al., 1977; van Geel et al., 2003, 2008). In modern coprophilous fungal communities, the presence and abundance of particular fungal species is affected by climatic factors, such as precipitation (moisture availability) and temperature (Angel and Wicklow, 1983; Masunga et al., 2006; Richardson, 2001; Yocom and Wicklow, 1980). It is plausible therefore to suspect that the representation of fungal spores in sediments might also be influenced by climatic factors. There is a need to clarify the importance and relative contributions of climatic, morphologic, and land use variables on Sporormiella representation in terrestrial and lacustrine records.

An increasing number of studies are relating Sporormiella abundances in contemporary sediments to herbivore abundance and grazing history, using soil and leaf-litter samples (Blackford and Innes, 2006; Cordova et al., 2011; Graf and Chmura, 2006) and modern and historic lake sediments (Davis and Shafer, 2006; Raper and Bush, 2009). These studies conclude that Sporormiella is an indicator of highly localized grazing and, in historic sediments, is often but not always present in high abundance when herbivores are present. Graf and Chmura (2006), for example, successfully used coprophilous fungi as indicators of grazed versus ungrazed plots. Sporormiella was also present in the dung of moa and other avian herbivores from New Zealand and Sporormiella abundances in soil cores appears to track their decline (Wood et al., 2011). Sporormiella abundance has been linked to the nearby density of megaherbivores in historic sediments, (Raper and Bush, 2009), but the scale at which cattle density controls Sporormiella representation remains unclear. Raper and Bush (2009) showed that high Sporormiella abundances are associated with nearby grazing cattle, but also reported within-lake variations in Sporormiella concentrations. They found that Sporormiella concentrations rapidly decreased within the first 20 m from shore, presumably due to the limited dispersal capability of Sporormiella. Given these findings, Raper and Bush (2009) proposed an alternate hypothesis for the Late-Pleistocene and Holocene Sporormiella declines, i.e. that they may have been caused by rising lake levels that increased the distance between the cored location and the Sporormiella source area.

Here we investigate whether regional-scale spatial patterns in Sporormiella abundances are affected by factors such as climate and megaherbivore density, in order to better understand the processes that control temporal variations in Sporormiella abundances in lake sediments. Using a collection of 24 lakes from an east–west transect across the northern Great Plains of the USA, we investigate the relative importance of a collection of climatic, morphologic, and land-use variables on the representation of Sporormiella within and across lake basins. We then discuss the implications of these results for interpretation of Sporormiella in the modern and fossil record.

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: The Great Plains is characterized by a steep and relatively uniform precipitation gradient (Figure 1), with drier conditions to the west, resulting in a gradual change in vegetation from eastern deciduous forests, dominated by Quercus (oak), Ulmus (elm), Fraxinus (ash), Populus (poplar), Acer (maple), and Betula (birch) changing westwards to tallgrass and shortgrass prairie and finally a shrub steppe (McAndrews and Wright, 1969). The gradual and consistent change in precipitation and the resulting change in vegetation makes the Great Plains a classic area for gradient analyses of the effect of moisture-related climatic factors on ecological processes, both present (Bradford et al., 2006; Epstein et al., 1996; Lane et al., 1998) and past (Clark et al., 2001; Grimm, 2001; Nelson and Hu, 2008).

caption.p: (a) Site locations overlying mean annual precipitation from WorldClim (Hijmans et al., 2005). (b) Site locations overlying cattle/acre by county (USDA NASS) and the proportion of land used as pasture (Ramankutty et al., 2008)

sec.p: The variation in cattle density and pasture extent across the Great Plains further enhances this region as a place to study the controls on Sporormiella representation (Figure 1). Moving from west to east there is a rapid increase from pasture to cropland (Figure 1), but the county-level cattle density shows a different pattern, with distinct clusters of high cattle density in eastern South Dakota and the Driftless Area of southwestern Wisconsin. Free-range grazing is most prominent in South Dakota, while in Wisconsin dairy farming and feedlot enclosures are the primary form of cattle rearing.

sec.title: Field methods
sec.p: We sampled 24 lakes across a west–east transect through southern South Dakota, Minnesota, and Wisconsin (Figure 1, Table 1) to investigate the impact of aridity, basin morphology, and land-use variables on the abundances of Sporormiella. Sample sites were chosen using Google Earth, road atlases, and field observation and were based primarily on accessibility (proximity to access roads), size, and spacing along the transect.

caption.p: Compilation of site descriptions. ID numbers are referenced in the text

sec.p: Two surface samples were collected at each lake: one from near the lake margin (10–50 m from the margin depending on accessibility. These distances were estimated in the field and then verified using Google Earth) and the other from the lake ‘center’, defined here as the deepest part of the basin. At some lakes we took multiple samples if we did not collect sufficient sediment in the first attempt. To measure water depth, we lowered a Secchi disk to the sediment–water interface with meter increments marked along the rope. The top 5 to 10 cm of sediment were collected using a Hongve gravity sampler. Amount of sediment retrieved (depth in cm) was recorded, and samples were described and stored in coolers with ice. Spatial coordinates of each sampling point were taken using a handheld GPS unit. At each site the presence or absence of cattle, pigs, geese, or other potential coprophilous fungal hosts were noted, and when present, their abundance was estimated qualitatively. It was not always clear whether cattle had access to the water’s edge, although access to the lakes is more probable at the western sites, where free-range grazing is more common.

sec.title: Pollen analysis
sec.p: In the lab, pollen and spores were extracted from the sediment using standard processing methods (Faegri and Iversen, 1989). 10 ml of sediment was processed for each sample (20 ml for highly flocculent samples). To measure concentration, samples were spiked with Lycopodium tablets (stored in a calcium carbonate base) of known concentration (18 583 spores per tablet, 3 tablets = 55 749 ± 2292 spores added per sample).

For each sample, we performed a count of at least 350 grains (arboreal plants, herbs, aquatics, and fungi), identifying pollen types as well as Sporormiella and other coprophilous fungi. Modern reference materials and keys from Kapp et al. (2000) and Doveri (2007) were used to identify pollen and fungal spores, respectively. Though rare, when Sporormiella was present in chains, spores were counted individually. Asci, the Sporormiella spore-bearing cells, were counted separately from spores and were excluded from the percent abundance and concentration data. Percent abundances were calculated relative to a sum consisting of all pollen and fungal types. Pollen and fungal concentrations were calculated by multiplying the ratio of counted pollen and spores to counted Lycopodium by the known concentration of Lycopodium spores (Stockmarr, 1971).

sec.title: Other data sources and statistical analyses
sec.p: We obtained climatic data from WorldClim (Hijmans et al., 2005), which consists of climatic averages calculated from weather station data for ad 1960 to 1990. We compiled county-level cattle density data from the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Survey (http://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/), by collecting the number of total beef and milk cows per county, reported at the end of 2007. We then divided this by county area, resulting in individual cows/acre per county. We gathered lake depth and area from the Department of Natural Resources websites for each state. Information on the proportion of land area used as cropland and pasture is from the Global Agricultural Lands in the Year 2000 data set (Ramankutty et al., 2008). We used the ‘extract values to points’ function in ArcGIS version 9.1 by ESRI to assign the climatic and land use values to the lat/lon coordinates for each lake. This function uses bilinear interpolation to interpolate a value from the center of the grid cell to each target point. Because Sporormiella is thought to be a highly local indicator of grazing, the climatic and land use data at each point are the most relevant for these analyses.

We used multiple linear regression models to assess the relative importance of climate, county-level herbivore density, land use, and basin characteristics as predictors of the percent abundance and concentration of Sporormiella. We used a stepwise multiple linear regression model (StepAIC, specifying that the direction = ‘both’, in R version 2.10.1) which uses a combination of forward variable selection and backward elimination, assessing whether variables should be added or dropped after each stage of selection. Variable selection is based on the Akaike Information Criteria (AIC) measure of the goodness of fit of the model to the data. We square-root transformed the Sporormiella relative abundance and concentration data because it resulted in a more normal distribution. Normality was assessed based on inspection of histograms of distributions and Quantile-Quantile plots. The following potential predictor variables were included in the models: mean annual precipitation (MAP), mean annual temperature (MAT), precipitation of the wettest month, precipitation of the driest month, temperature of the warmest month, temperature of the coldest month, land use (percent pasture, based on raster data at a spatial scale of about 10 km), lake type (dammed versus natural), cattle per acre by county, lake area, lake maximum depth, and distance to shore (for the margin samples). We calculated a multiple linear regression model for each Sporormiella-related response variable (margin concentration, margin percent abundance, center concentration, center percent abundance). We then assessed statistical significance and variance explained by the models using p-values, r2, and adjusted r2 values (which downweight r2 values for models with more predictor variables). To reduce the effects of co-linearity among climatic variables we ran an annual model which included MAP and MAT as climatic variables and a seasonal model which included precipitation of the wettest/driest months and temperature of the warmest/coldest months as alternatives to the annual climatic data.

sec.title: General trends
sec.p: Consistent with previous studies of the abundance of Sporormiella in historic sediments (Cordova et al., 2011; Davis and Shafer, 2006), percent abundances of Sporormiella in the surface sediments are high at many sites. Percentages reach >4% of the pollen sum in the margin samples and >3% in the center samples, mainly in the SD and MN sites in the middle of the transect (Figures 1, 2). We also found asci, the spore-bearing cells containing many chains of Sporormiella (Figure 2). Some asci were full of spores while others appeared to have burst and were empty. Asci were more common in lake-margin samples; two of the 24 sites contained eight asci. Asci appeared to be more common in samples with high Sporormiella abundances (Figure 2), but the relationship is not strong. Of the two sites with eight asci, one had 0.86% Sporormiella while the other had 4.85% Sporormiella.

caption.p: Distribution of pollen and spore types along the transect. All data is for lake-center samples, except for Sporormiella, which also has lake-margin data shown. Number of asci are noted in the Sporormiella panels above the samples in which they are present

sec.p: The following coprophilous fungi were also present in our samples: Podospora-type, and Coprinus-type, as well as fungi within the order Sordariales, some of which are coprophilous (Figure 2 illustrates the three coprophilous types combined). We also identified Chaetomium, a cellulose decomposer, which is sometimes found on dung when mixed with straw (van Geel et al., 2003). Non-coprophilous fungal types identified include Fusarium, a common tree fungus, Neurospora, Aureobasidium-type, Panaeolus, Pleospora, and Ustulina. All other fungal spores not exhibiting defining features were counted but not identified to type. There is no significant correlation between Sporormiella percent abundance and the percent abundance of the other coprophilous types (Podospora- and Coprinus-type) in the margin or center samples (margin: r2 = 0.0078, p = 0.683; center: r2 = 0.109, p = 0.115). Other pollen taxa show the expected east to west trends, with the percent abundance of arboreal taxa increasing to the east and the non-arboreal taxa declining in abundance. Among non-arboreal types there is a west-to-east transition from high percentages of Artemisia to Ambrosia and finally to Poaceae. Ambrosia abundances are highest in the middle of the transect, reaching up to 40% of the total pollen sum. Some western sites have a high percentage of Pinus which is likely due to long distance dispersal from the Black Hills of South Dakota because these sites are predominantly grassland. To the east, Pinus and Quercus abundances gradually increase, which is the expected trend for these taxa (McAndrews and Wright, 1969).

sec.title: Lake-center versus lake-margin samples and percentage versus concentration data
sec.p: The relative abundance and concentration of Sporormiella are uncorrelated between lake-margin and lake-center samples (Figure 3). The lack of a correlation between lake-margin and lake-center concentrations is not a general phenomenon, because other taxa, e.g. Quercus, Pinus, and Ambrosia, reveal strong positive correlations (Figure 3; Quercus and Ambrosia not shown). Although Sporormiella lake-center percentages appear to be higher than lake-margin percentages in the west (Figure 2), the means across the entire transect are similar (lake-margin mean = 1.21%, lake-center mean = 1.24%).

caption.p: The relationship between lake-margin and lake-center Sporormiella percent abundance ((a) p = 0.291, r2 = 0.0506) and concentration ((b) p = 0.841, r2 = 0.00187) and between lake-margin and lake-center Pinus abundances ((c) p < 0.001, r2 = 0.511) and concentrations ((d) p < 0.001, r2 = 0.47). Sporormiella abundances, unlike Pinus, show no significant correlation between lake-margin and lake-center samples

sec.p: The lake-margin samples were taken at varying distances from shore (Figire 4). When Sporormiella concentrations are regressed against distance to shore there is a strong positive relationship (p = 0.008, r2 = 0.279; Figure 4) and relative abundances reveal the same general trend, but more weakly (p = 0.059, r2 = 0.153; Figure 4).

caption.p: Relationship between Sporormiella representation (percent abundance: p = 0.059, r2 = 0.153 (a) and concentration: = 0.008, r2 = 0.279 (b)) and distance to shore (m)

sec.title: Climatic, land-use, and basin predictors of Sporormiella abundance
sec.p: MAP and precipitation of the driest month were significantly negatively correlated to Sporormiella percent abundance in lake-center samples. No climate variables were significantly correlated to Sporormiella percentages in lake-margin samples (Figure 5, Table 2). Sporormiella abundance is not correlated with county-level cattle density data (USDA NASS data) in linear regression models where cattle density is the only potential predictor (Figure 6).

caption.p: Percent abundance of Sporormiella regressed against MAP (a) and precipitation of the driest month (b). The gray lines represents the margin samples ((a) p = 0.244, r2 = 0.0612, (b) p = 0.123, r2 = 0.109) and the black lines represents the center samples ((a) p < 0.001, r2 = 0.600, (b) p = 1.75 × 10−5, r2 = 0.593)

Results of the multiple linear regression models. Predictor variables that were not significant are not shown. The p, r2, and adjusted r2 values, as well as equations for the models are noted. For Model 3, x1 represents distance to shore and x2 represents cattle per acre

tr.td: Distance to shore Cattle per acre

caption.p: County-scale cattle density versus percent abundance Sporormiella (a) and concentration (b). The red represents margin data and the black represents center data. Percent abundance is not related to cattle/acre (margin: p = 0.886, r2 = 0.001; center: p = 0.679, r2 = 0.008) and neither is concentration (margin samples: p = 0.879, r2 = 0.001; center samples: p = 0.802, r2 = 0.003)

sec.p:
In the multiple-regression analyses, precipitation of the driest month is the strongest predictor of lake-center Sporormiella percentages (Table 2), consistent with the simple linear regression results. Distance to shore is a significant predictor variable for both margin-percent and margin-concentration response variables (p = 0.034, p = 0.008, respectively). Cattle per acre is also a significant predictor variable for the margin-percent model, albeit with a slightly smaller p-value than for distance-to-shore (p = 0.047). No significant predictors were found for the center concentration data. Overall, there is less unexplained variance in the relative abundance data than in the concentration data (center: r2 = 0.5926 versus no significant predictors; margin:

= 0.5156 versus

= 0.3101; Table 2I).

sec.title: Climatic controls on Sporormiella abundance
sec.p: Our results reveal several apparent correlations between climate and Sporormiella representation. The negative correlation between center percent abundance data and seasonal and annual precipitation (Figure 5, Table 2) is somewhat surprising given that moisture is important in modern fungal community diversity (Richardson, 2001); fungal diversity is higher in cool, moist conditions (Wicklow and Angel, 1980) and one might expect that fungal abundances also would be higher in moist substrates. Several mechanisms might explain this relationship. First, climatic preferences vary among fungal taxa (Richardson, 2001), so it is possible that Sporormiella is present but less abundant in moist environments. Alternatively, higher rainfall in the east might reduce the number of Sporormiella spores becoming airborne, reducing its dispersal distance and representation in lake sediments. Lastly, the negative relationship between relative abundances and precipitation simply may be an effect of the higher influx of arboreal pollen in the east, which drives down the relative abundance of Sporormiella. This interpretation is supported by the absence of significant correlation between Sporormiella lake-center concentrations and MAP.

sec.title: Megaherbivore controls on Sporormiella abundance
sec.p: County-level cattle density was a significant predictor of Sporormiella abundances, but only for the lake-margin relative abundance data and only when cattle density was included with distance-to-shore in a multiple linear regression model. This suggests that megaherbivore density is a significant influence on Sporormiella abundances, but that this effect can be obscured by other factors. One such factor may be differences in cattle husbandry within the Great Plains. Examination of Figures 1 and 2 suggests that western counties with high cattle density may have higher Sporormiella abundances than eastern counties with high cattle density, although the sample size here is too small for this to be a statistically significant pattern. If so, this may reflect a shift from more open-range pasturing in the west to more fenced-in feedlots to the east. Clearly, information about local cattle densities around each lake would be preferable, but this information is difficult to obtain given the large range areas involved, the regional trend towards increasing absentee land ownership, and the difficulty of obtaining historical data over the several decades represented by these samples. We attempted on-site observations of cattle density, but are not confident in this as a measure of recent herbivore density.

sec.title: Basin controls on Sporormiella abundance: within- and across-lake variation
sec.p: The basin morphologic characteristics (lake depth, area, and basin type) are not strong predictor variables for Sporormiella variation. Similarly, differences in margin versus center sample data are not explained by these characteristics. One challenge is that some of these predictor variables are correlated across the transect (e.g. the frequency of dams increases to the west, pasture is more abundant to the west, etc.).

Our analyses suggest that the within-lake variations of Sporormiella are higher than for other pollen types. The data show no relationship between the lake-margin and lake-center abundances of Sporormiella, for both percent abundance and concentration data (Figure 3). Conversely, similar analyses of key arboreal and non-arboreal taxa (Pinus, Quercus, and Ambrosia) reveal strong positive linear relationships between lake-margin and lake-center data (relative abundance: Pinus: p < 0.001, r2 = 0.511; Quercus: p = 8.4 × 10−10, r2 = 0.8255; Ambrosia: p = 0.005, r2 = 0.308; concentration: Pinus: p < 0.001, r2 = 0.47; Quercus: p = 9.83 × 10−9, r2 = 0.782; Ambrosia: p = 6.25 × 10−5, r2 = 0.525; Figure 3). Therefore we should be cautious in our interpretation of the Sporormiella data because of the various factors that influence its variability. Overall, various regression models explained less of the variation in the concentration data than in the relative abundance data. Pollen concentrations are strongly influenced by sedimentation rate and can vary by a factor of up to ten in a small lake basin (Davis et al., 1973). This result is consistent with other reports that for heterogenous multilake data sets, relative abundances will be less noisy than concentration data (Davis et al., 1973).

sec.title: Comparison with previous work
sec.p: A key predecessor to this work is Raper and Bush (2009), in which 15 lakes in ungrazed and grazed landscapes in central Florida were sampled to test the relationship between Sporormiella concentration and local cattle density. At each site a lake-center and lake-margin sample was analyzed, and for three lakes Raper and Bush collected a transect of four samples from lake-margin to lake-center (at 0, 20, 50, and 100 m from shoreline). They reported that Sporormiella concentrations were greater in lake-margin sediments where cattle grazed and Sporormiella was absent in the center samples of all lakes where cattle were absent. The intra-lake transects also showed that Sporormiella concentrations rapidly decreased within the first 20 m from shore.

Given the Raper and Bush (2009) findings, we were surprised to find a positive linear relationship between distance to shore and Sporormiella concentrations (Figure 4). Although the reason for this discrepancy is not known with certainty, there are some likely possibilities. First, the effect of shoreline proximity on Sporormiella representation may be limited to very short distances from shoreline. In the within-lake transects of Raper and Bush (2009), the decrease in Sporormiella abundances is limited to samples collected at the shoreline versus samples collected 20 m from shore; no trend in Sporormiella abundances is apparent at distances beyond 20 m (Raper and Bush, 2009: figure 5). Similarly, both this paper and the interlake analyses from Raper and Bush (2009) show no significant relationship between Sporormiella concentrations between nearshore and center-lake samples (Raper and Bush, 2009: figure 8). These findings together suggest that interlake variations in Sporormiella concentrations are strongly affected by differences in basin morphology and hence sediment focusing. This conclusion is consistent with prior studies showing high variation in pollen concentrations and accumulation rates within and among lakes (Davis et al., 1973); our analyses suggest that these variations are even more pronounced for locally produced and weakly dispersed Sporormiella than for other regionally dispersed pollen types (Figure 3). Perhaps larger lakes exhibit more sediment focusing and hence concentrate Sporormiella more at the center. It would be valuable to collect more within-lake transects as done by Raper and Bush (2009) as well as collect short cores to observe how the Sporormiella signature of the European reintroduction of megaherbivores varies within lakes.

Raper and Bush (2009) hypothesized that climatic changes that produced rising lake level could be responsible for the Late-Pleistocene Sporormiella declines, by increasing the distance from the lake center to the Sporormiella source. As discussed above, we suggest that this effect of shoreline position on Sporormiella abundances may be limited to very short distances, i.e. within 20 m of shoreline. However, our finding that center percent abundance of Sporormiella decreases with increasing precipitation (Figure 5) may support the Raper and Bush hypothesis via another mechanism, i.e. decreased aridity might increase the influx of arboreal pollen types and thereby drive down the relative abundances of Sporormiella. This mechanism should affect the relative abundance data only, not Sporormiella concentrations, so the reality of apparent declines in Sporormiella relative abundances should be checked against trends in concentration data (Gill et al., 2009). Note that Faith (2011) has suggested that increasing aridity might also be implicated in the Late-Pleistocene megafaunal declines in North America, via its effects on nitrogen cycling and plant nitrogen content.

Our paper generally supports the conclusions by others that Sporormiella is a highly localized signal of grazing. Raper and Bush (2009) reported a positive association between cattle density (per meter of shoreline) and Sporormiella concentrations in shoreline sediments. Davis and Shafer (2006) showed that Sporormiella is abundant in historic sediments and archaeological sites where livestock were once abundant. Graf and Chmura (2006) reveal that coprophilous fungi are in highest abundance in manured/grazed landscapes, while Blackford and Innes (2006) found similar results in grazed woodland environments.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study shows that Sporormiella representation in lake sediments is influenced by multiple factors, including but not limited to megaherbivore densities. Other key factors include aridity (mainly through its effect on the abundances of other pollen types) and within-lake sedimentary processes. Within-lake variations for Sporormiella are higher than for other pollen types, confirming prior reports that Sporormiella dispersal and deposition is highly localized. Sporormiella concentrations appear to be more influenced by local sedimentary processes than Sporormiella relative abundances, consistent with prior studies of the deposition and resuspension of pollen within lakes. Although the widely observed Sporormiella declines in Late-Pleistocene and Holocene sediments may well be linked to the global wave of megafaunal extinctions, the results of this study point to the possible influence of other factors, and more work is needed to understand the factors controlling the representation of Sporormiella in lake sediments. Key steps forward include more process-based studies of Sporormiella transport to and within lakes, and more studies of Sporormiella representation within lakes, using additional regional-scale analyses, within-lake transects, and short cores spanning the historic re-introduction of domesticated herbivores.

ack.p: We thank Jessica Blois, Jacquelyn Gill, Emelie McKain, Sam Muñoz, Grace Schellinger and Sam Veloz for assistance with this project. Michael Richardson suggested useful resources for Sporormiella identification. We thank Eric Grimm for loaning field equipment and assistance with pollen identifications. This manuscript was improved by comments from Sara Hotchkiss, Joe Mason, and two anonymous reviewers.
